name: Set Membership Relation
formal_statement: The relation $x \in A$ read as 'x is an element of A' or 'x belongs to A' is the fundamental primitive relation of set theory.
informal_description: The basic relationship between an object and a collection (set) that contains it. Like saying 'this apple is in this basket' or 'this student is in this class'.

examples.explanation: The number 3 is an element of the set containing 1, 2, 3, and 4
The letter 'a' belongs to the set of first five letters
The number 5 is NOT an element of this set
Sets can themselves be elements of other sets

counterexamples.explanation: The SET containing 2 is not an element of this set; only the NUMBER 2 is

historical_context: Introduced by Georg Cantor in the late 19th century as the foundation of set theory. The symbol ∈ was first used by Giuseppe Peano in 1889, derived from the first letter of the Greek word 'ἐστί' (esti), meaning 'is'.
pedagogical_notes: Use concrete examples before abstract ones. Common confusion: element vs. subset relationship. Emphasize that ∈ relates an object to a set, while ⊆ relates sets to sets.

steps: List all elements of the set
Check if the object appears in this list

applications: Programming (checking if item is in array/list)

relationships.description: Extensionality axiom is stated in terms of membership
Subset relation is defined using membership
